title: Constructing Query-Driven Evidence Graph On-the-Fly for GraphRAG
authors: Manzong Huang, Chenyang Bu, Yi He, Xingrui Zhuo, Xindong Wu
keywords: GraphRAG, Knowledge Graph, Large Language Models, Retrieval-Augmented Generation, Open-Domain Question Answering
summary: Relink proposes a dynamic framework for constructing query-specific evidence graphs to address the limitations of static Knowledge Graphs in GraphRAG, achieving significant improvements in accuracy.

title: Beyond Variance: Knowledge-Aware LLM Compression via Fisher-Aligned Subspace Diagnostics
authors: Ibne Farabi Shihab, Sanjeda Akter, Anuj Sharma
keywords: LLM Compression, Fisher Information Matrix, Activation Compression, SVD, Knowledge Preservation, Transformer Architectures
summary: FASC is a knowledge-aware compression framework for LLMs that preserves factual knowledge by selecting subspaces based on activation-gradient coupling, outperforming variance-based methods in accuracy on knowledge-intensive benchmarks.

title: Forward versus Backward: Comparing Reasoning Objectives in Direct Preference Optimization
keywords: reasoning capabilities, hallucination, Direct Preference Optimization, chain-of-thought generation, verification, GSM8K, Low-Rank Adaptation
summary: This paper investigates the effect of training objective composition on reasoning reliability through Direct Preference Optimization, comparing forward chain-of-thought generation and backward verification, revealing distinct and complementary learning signals.

title: Safeguarding LLM Fine-tuning via Push-Pull Distributional Alignment
authors: Haozhong Wang, Zhuo Li, Yibo Yang, He Zhao, Hongyuan Zha, Dandan Guo
keywords: LLM, fine-tuning, safety alignment, Optimal Transport, data distribution, model safety
summary: Introducing Safety Optimal Transport (SOT) to enhance model safety during LLM fine-tuning by aligning data distributions and establishing a robust safety boundary.

title: CalPro: Prior-Aware Evidential–Conformal Prediction with Structure-Aware Guarantees for Protein Structures
authors: Ibne Farabi Shihab, Sanjeda Akter, Anuj Sharma
keywords: protein structure prediction, uncertainty quantification, conformal prediction, evidential learning, distribution shift, calibration
summary: CalPro introduces a prior-aware evidential–conformal framework for robust uncertainty quantification in protein structure prediction, achieving improved calibration and coverage under distribution shifts.

filename: 2601.07206v1_LLMRouterBench A Massive Benchmark and Unified Fra.pdf
title: LLMRouterBench: A Massive Benchmark and Unified Framework for LLM Routing
authors: Hao Li, Yiqun Zhang, Zhaoyan Guo, Chenxu Wang, Shengji Tang, Qiaosheng Zhang, Yang Chen, Biqing Qi, Peng Ye, Lei Bai, Zhen Wang, Shuyue Hu
keywords: LLM routing, benchmark, framework, performance, cost trade-off, model ensemble
summary: LLMRouterBench is a large-scale benchmark and unified framework for LLM routing, comprising over 400K instances from 21 datasets and 33 models, providing comprehensive metrics for performance-oriented and performance-cost trade-off routing.

title: SIRR-LMM: Single-image Reflection Removal via Large Multimodal Model
authors: Yu Guo, Zhiqiang Lao, Xiyun Song, Yubin Zhou, Heather Yu
keywords: Single-image Reflection Removal, Large Multimodal Model, Synthetic Dataset, Path-tracing, LoRA
summary: This paper introduces a synthetic dataset generation framework for single-image reflection removal using a Large Multimodal Model, achieving improved performance over state-of-the-art methods.

title: BlindU: Blind Machine Unlearning without Revealing Erasing Data
authors: Weiqi Wang, Zhiyi Tian, Chenhan Zhang, Shui Yu
keywords: Machine Unlearning, Federated Learning, Privacy Leakage, Privacy Preserving, Information Bottleneck
summary: This paper proposes Blind Unlearning (BlindU) to enable machine unlearning without revealing erasing data to the server, using compressed representations and a noise-free differential privacy masking method.

title: Consolidation or Adaptation? PRISM: Disentangling SFT and RL Data via Gradient Concentration
authors: Yang Zhao, Yangou Ouyang, Xiao Ding, Hepeng Wang, Bibo Cai, Kai Xiong, Jinglong Gao, Zhouhao Sun, Li Du, Bing Qin, Ting Liu
keywords: Hybrid Supervised Fine-Tuning, Reinforcement Learning, Gradient Concentration, Schema Theory, Data Arbitration, Large Language Models, Agent Alignment
summary: PRISM is a framework that arbitrates data between Supervised Fine-Tuning and Reinforcement Learning based on gradient concentration, improving alignment efficiency and reducing computational costs.

filename: 2601.07226v1_Lost in the Noise How Reasoning Models Fail with C.pdf
title: Lost in the Noise: How Reasoning Models Fail with Contextual Distractors
authors: Seongyun Lee, Yongrae Jo, Minju Seo, Moontae Lee, Minjoon Seo
keywords: reasoning models, contextual distractors, NoisyBench, robustness, RAG, tool-use tasks, agentic AI systems, Rationale-Aware Reward (RARE)
summary: The paper introduces NoisyBench, a benchmark evaluating model robustness against diverse noise types, revealing significant performance drops in state-of-the-art models due to contextual distractors.

filename: 2601.07229v2_DiSCo Making Absence Visible in Intelligent Summar.pdf
title: DiSCo: Making Absence Visible in Intelligent Summarization Interfaces
authors: ERAN FAINMAN, HAGIT BEN SHOSHAN, ADIR SOLOMON, OSNAT MOKRYN
keywords: Human-centered computing, User studies, Information systems, Expert systems, Computing methodologies, Artificial intelligence, Review Summarization, Absence, Expectations, Learning via surprisability, Missing commonalities
summary: DiSCo is an expectation-based computational approach that makes absences visible in intelligent summarization interfaces by comparing content with domain topical expectations, improving transparency and decision support.

filename: 2601.07232v1_Yes FLoReNce I Will Do Better Next Time Agentic Fe.pdf
title: Y es FLoReNce, I Will Do Better Next Time! Agentic Feedback Reasoning for Humorous Meme Detection
authors: Olivia Shanhong Liu, Pai Chet Ng, De Wen Soh, Konstantinos N. Plataniotis
keywords: humorous meme detection, agentic feedback reasoning, multimodal models, AI systems, humor interpretation
summary: FLoReNce is a framework that improves meme humor understanding by using a closed-loop feedback process during learning and an open-loop process during inference, enhancing predictive performance and explanation quality.

filename: 2601.07233v1_From Thinking to Justifying Aligning High-Stakes E.pdf
title: From “Thinking” to “Justifying”: Aligning High-Stakes Explainability with Professional Communication Standards
authors: Chen Qian, Yimeng Wang, Yu Chen, Lingfei Wu, Andreas Stathopoulos
keywords: Explainable AI, Chain-of-Thought, Structured Explainability Framework, High-Stakes Domains, Professional Communication Standards
summary: The paper proposes a 'Result → Justify' approach for Explainable AI in high-stakes domains, introducing SEF to improve verifiability and reliability by aligning with professional communication standards.

filename: 2601.07238v1_Group Pattern Selection Optimization Let LRMs Pick.pdf
title: Group Pattern Selection Optimization: Let LRMs Pick the Right Pattern for Reasoning
authors: Hanbin Wang, Jingwei Song, Jinpeng Li, Fei Mi, Lifeng Shang
keywords: Large reasoning models, reinforcement learning, pattern selection, mathematics benchmarks, science benchmarks, Chain-of-Thought, Proximal Policy Optimization, GRPO
summary: This paper introduces Group Pattern Selection Optimization (GPSO), a reinforcement learning framework that enables large reasoning models to select optimal reasoning patterns for different problems, leading to consistent performance improvements across various benchmarks.

title: Stochastic CHAOS: Why Deterministic Inference Kills, and Distributional Variability Is the Heartbeat of Artificial Cognition
authors: Tanmay Joshi, Shourya Aggarwal, Anusa Saha, Aadi Pandey, Shreyash Dhoot, Vighnesh Rai, Raxit Goswami, Aman Chadha, Vinija Jain, Amitava Das
keywords: Large Language Models, Deterministic Inference, Stochastic Inference, Distributional Variability, Artificial Cognition, Reproducibility, Uncertainty Modeling, Emergent Abilities, Reasoning, Safety Alignment
summary: The paper argues that deterministic inference in large language models (LLMs) limits their ability to model uncertainty, disrupts reasoning, and makes safety alignment brittle, advocating for stochastic inference to harness distributional variability as the core of artificial cognition.
